round_data.prompt:
You and another agent have to negotiate a division of items between the two of you.
    You are Player 1 and the other agent is Player 2.
    There are 5 types of items, called item 1 through item 5.
    There are 2 units of item 1, 4 units of item 2, 5 units of item 3, 5 units of item 4, 2 units of item 5 to divide.
    Both you and Player 2 have a private value per unit of each item type.
    These values are drawn from a uniform random distribution, ranging from 1 to 101.
    Your private values are 42 for item 1, 18 for item 2, 79 for item 3, 61 for item 4, 4 for item 5.
    You have a private outside offer drawn from a uniform random distribution ranging from 1 to your total value of all items, which is 864. Player 2 has a private outside offer drawn from a uniform random distribution ranging from 1 to to their total value of all items.
    Your outside offer value is 757. 

    The negotiation proceeds in 3 rounds.
    There is a discount rate gamma = 0.9, such that if the process concludes after r rounds the overall value of the negotiation to each player is their value for the outcome multiplied by gamma to the power (r-1).
    At each round, Player 1 takes an action, followed by Player 2.
    The possible actions are to ACCEPT the other player's current offer (if any), make a COUNTEROFFER, or WALK away.  If the game gets to the last round, and player 2 chooses to make a counteroffer, this is treated as a WALK.
    If a player chooses ACCEPT, the negotiation ends in a deal to divide the items according to the accepted offer.
    The value of an outcome is determined by each player's private values per unit of each item and the quantities they receive in the deal. This value is adjusted by the discount factor, which is used to compute the present value of the negotiation outcome.
    If a player chooses WALK, the negotiation ends without a deal, and each player receives the value of their private outside offer.

    Please show your reasoning step by step, then provide your action in one of these formats in your response (if you do not do this your response will be invalid):
    {"action": "ACCEPT"} - to accept the current offer
    {"action": "WALK"} - to walk away from negotiations  
    {"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [n1, n2, ...]} - where n1, n2, ... are numbers representing the number of units of each item being offered to the other player as part of the counteroffer.

    Any response not in these exact formats will be invalid and treated as a WALK. If you provide a counteroffer, it must be a valid offer, otherwise it will be treated as a WALK.

    It is now round 1.
    
 Negotiation history:

Current offer on the table (the amount of each item being offered to you): None

        What is your action? As the first player, your available actions are:
        - WALK to walk away
        - A list of numbers [n1, n2, ...] representing your initial offer (what you give to Player 2)
round_data.response:
Step‐by‐step reasoning:

1. We begin by calculating our total “full‐bundle” value. With our private per‐unit values
  • Item 1 (2 units): 2×42 = 84
  • Item 2 (4 units): 4×18 = 72
  • Item 3 (5 units): 5×79 = 395 
  • Item 4 (5 units): 5×61 = 305 
  • Item 5 (2 units): 2×4 = 8
  Total = 84+72+395+305+8 = 864.
  Our outside offer is 757. Thus if no deal is reached we “fall‐back” to 757. Consequently any deal must give us more than 757 (when undiscounted, as we are at round 1 with gamma^(0)=1).

2. Our “surplus” is 864 – 757 = 107. In other words, in the negotiation we can at most “give away” items worth 107 in our own evaluation and still beat disagreement. (Our outcome value equals 864 minus the total “cost” in our own values of what we concede to player 2.)

3. Because we know our own values exactly, we want to keep our high‐value items. For us the most valuable items are item 3 (value 79/unit) and item 4 (value 61/unit) – we want to keep those. We also prefer to keep item 1 (42/unit). Items 2 (18/unit) and 5 (4/unit) are “cheaper” relative to their number of units. Conceding some of these may help induce player 2 to agree while costing us relatively little.

4. One strategy is to offer player 2 the full quantity of items 2 and 5. Conceding:
  • Item 2: 4 units × 18 = 72
  • Item 5: 2 units × 4 = 8
  Total “cost” = 72+8 = 80.
  This leaves us with a value of 864 – 80 = 784, which is comfortably above 757 (a surplus of 27). This generous offer on the “cheaper” items may be attractive for player 2 while protecting our high‐value items.

5. This offer – giving player 2 all of items 2 and 5, and keeping all of items 1, 3, and 4 – is valid (it respects the available quantities) and keeps our own payoff above our disagreement threshold.

6. Hence, as our opening move in Round 1 we propose the following offer (noting that in our protocol the offer is the list of units given to player 2 for items 1 through 5): [0, 4, 0, 0, 2].

Based on the above reasoning my action is:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [0, 4, 0, 0, 2]}

Step‐by‐step reasoning:

1. Our private values (per unit) for the items are:
 – Item 1: 42  Item 2: 18  Item 3: 79  Item 4: 61  Item 5: 4

2. The total available quantities are [2, 4, 5, 5, 2]. Thus, if we took everything we would get a “raw” (undiscounted) value of:
  2×42 + 4×18 + 5×79 + 5×61 + 2×4 = 84 + 72 + 395 + 305 + 8 = 864

3. In this negotiation the overall value is multiplied by a discount factor of γ^(round–1). We are now in round 2 so any deal reached would have its raw total multiplied by 0.9.

4. Our current outside offer (the “walk‐away” value) is 757, which we get immediately if we choose to WALK. If we were to accept a deal in round 2 then the deal’s raw value would be discounted by 0.9. In order for any deal to beat our 757 outside offer, the raw deal value would have to be more than 757/0.9 ≈ 841.  (Indeed, even getting all items would yield 0.9×864 = 777.6 which barely exceeds 757.)

5. The current offer on the table (Player 2’s offer to give us [1, 4, 0, 5, 0]) would give us a raw value of:
  1×42 + 4×18 + 0×79 + 5×61 + 0×4 = 42 + 72 + 0 + 305 = 419
 Discounted value in round 2: 0.9 × 419 ≈ 377.1, which is far below our outside offer of 757.

6. In a counteroffer we would aim to capture almost the entire value (since only by obtaining nearly everything could we beat 757 when discounted). However, any counteroffer that gives almost all value to us would likely offer Player 2 too little – and we don’t have information on his exact values. Such an extreme division may cause him to reject the deal and WALK (or not accept in the next round), leaving us with our outside offer anyway. Negotiation theory suggests that when your reservation value (here, 757) is very high relative to the discounted total value achievable from a deal, pushing for more in the division is very risky.

7. Given that the current offer yields only about 377 discounted and any aggressive counteroffer might risk losing a deal and force us into our high reservation outcome, our best risk–avoiding option is to WALK away and secure our outside offer of 757.

Therefore, our action in Round 2 is:

{"action": "WALK"}

round_data.response:
I’ll explain my reasoning briefly. My goal in round 1 is to propose an offer that – if accepted immediately (so no discount) – gives me more than my outside option (744 in my own valuation) while “incentivizing” Player 2 (whose unknown private values are drawn from the same uniform distribution) to prefer agreement over their disagreement offer. I know my own per‐unit “values” for the items:
• Item 1: 54 (for 3 units)
• Item 2: 64 (for 9 units)
• Item 3: 71 (for 3 units)
• Item 4: 1 (for 4 units)
• Item 5: 64 (for 6 units)

Since my own best interests means “keeping” most of the items I value highly (items 1, 2, 3, 5) and “giving away” those I value very little (item 4) I would naturally be tempted to keep nearly everything. However, if I offered Player 2 only item 4, they would get very little in their eyes even though they might actually (and typically do) value item 4 more than I do. (Because Player 2’s per‐unit values are drawn uniformly from 1 to 101, their likely number for item 4 is much higher than my “1.”) In order to make an offer that is acceptable to both sides, I need to “sweeten the deal” to Player 2 just enough so that—even if their disagreement (outside) payoff is reasonably high—they will see immediate agreement as attractive.

With this in mind I choose a counteroffer that transfers to Player 2:
 • Zero units of item 1 (so I keep all 3 units of item 1, which I value decently).
 • Four units of item 2 out of 9 (so I still keep 5 units—and 64 per unit is good for me).
 • One unit of item 3 (keeping 2 of 3, noting item 3 is my highest‐valued good).
 • All 4 units of item 4 (since I value them at only 1 each, but they are likely more attractive to Player 2).
 • Three units of item 5 (giving up 3 of 6 units, again sacrificing some “neutral” value to raise the offer).

Under this division, my retained bundle is:
 • Item 1: 3
 • Item 2: 5
 • Item 3: 2
 • Item 4: 0
 • Item 5: 3

That gives me my own value of approximately:
 3×54 + 5×64 + 2×71 + 0×1 + 3×64 = 162 + 320 + 142 + 0 + 192 = 816,
which is above my disagreement payoff (744).

For Player 2, even though I do not know their exact private values, a “generous” offer on item 4 (all units) plus a share of some other items (especially items 2, 3, and 5) should – under many likely draws – exceed what they could expect from their outside offer. (For example, if we assume they view items 1–3 and 5 around 50–64 per unit on average and item 4 even higher relative to my value, their total package can reasonably be estimated in a range that competes well with their disagreement.)

Thus, my strategy is to propose a Pareto‐efficient, nearly “splitting‐the‐surplus” offer with moderate generosity toward Player 2 while still ensuring I keep a good margin above my own outside option.

Based on this, my action is:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [0, 4, 1, 4, 3]}

I’ll explain my reasoning.

I want to “anchor” the deal so that if we agree immediately (at discount factor 1.0) I get at least as much as my outside option (742) while “sparing” the items that I value most. My personal total value if I got every unit is 978. That means if I were to “give up” only 978 – 742 = 236 (in my own valuation) then I would retain 742. I can choose to “sacrifice” (offer to Player 2) units of the items I care least about. In my valuation the per‐unit values are: item 1 = 9, item 2 = 41, item 3 = 89, item 4 = 7, and item 5 = 66. Hence the “cheapest” in my eyes are item 4 (7 per unit) and then item 1 (9 per unit). However there is not enough total quantity in these items to cover 236 if given completely. (3 units of item 1 give 27; 5 units of item 4 give 35; together only 62.) Thus I must also give some of item 2 (worth 41 per unit). In fact, if I give up everything in item 1 (27), everything in item 4 (35), and all of item 2 (4 units × 41 = 164), that “sacrifice” is a total of 27 + 35 + 164 = 226 in my terms. (This leaves me with 978 – 226 = 752 > 742 so I am safely above my reservation.) 

Thus I propose to offer Player 2 everything in these three item types:
 • Item 1: all 3 units
 • Item 2: all 4 units
 • Item 4: all 5 units
and to keep for myself all of the remaining items:
 • Item 3: all 4 units
 • Item 5: all 6 units

This division gives me 752 (4×89 + 6×66 = 356 + 396) in my value while Player 2 gets the “sacrifice” bundle (worth 27 + 164 + 35 = 226 in my terms). (Of course, Player 2’s own private values may differ; however, when making an offer, I want to start with a split that maximizes my share while leaving Player 2 a potentially competitive deal relative to their outside offer.) 

Thus my initial action is to make a counteroffer with the offer vector indicating the number of units offered to Player 2 as

  [3, 4, 0, 5, 0].

My answer in the required format is as follows:

[Reasoning]
We are in round 2. The current offer on the table (from Player 2) gives us [3, 3, 1, 4, 2]. With our private per‐unit values (9, 41, 89, 7, 66), this allocation would give us:
  item1: 3×9 = 27  
  item2: 3×41 = 123  
  item3: 1×89 = 89  
  item4: 4×7 = 28  
  item5: 2×66 = 132  
for a total of 27+123+89+28+132 = 399.  
But since we are in round 2 the deal is discounted by γ^(r–1)=0.9 so its present value is 0.9×399 ≈ 359.1.

We also have an outside offer (our “reservation”) of 742 (which is not discounted). Clearly 359.1 is far below what we can get by walking away. So we should not ACCEPT the current offer.

In a counteroffer our goal is to “improve” our share compared to our outside option. In every deal with discounting the items’ raw value is multiplied by 0.9. Thus we need to secure an outcome that, when discounted at 0.9, beats 742. In other words, our undisc­ounted value (the sum of values we get for our own items) should be at least about 742/0.9 ≈ 824.4.

Recall the total value (if we got everything) is 978. In a proposed division we offer Player 2 a bundle (as expressed by an array [x1,x2,x3,x4,x5]) and we get the complement. So our undiscounted payoff is:
  978 – [9·x1 + 41·x2 + 89·x3 + 7·x4 + 66·x5].
To achieve at least 824.4 for us, we must have
  9·x1 + 41·x2 + 89·x3 + 7·x4 + 66·x5 ≤ 978 – 824.4 = 153.6.

At the same time we want Player 2 to see enough “juice” to prefer a deal in round 2 rather than waiting for round 3 (or walking away into their own outside offer). Because we value differently than they likely do, the standard tactic is to “give” them items that are cheap for us (i.e. low per‑unit cost in our values) even if they might be more highly valued to them. For us the cheapest items are items 1 and 4 (costing 9 and 7 per unit respectively). 

A natural idea is to allocate the entire supply of items 1 and 4 to Player 2. That is, x1 = 3 and x4 = 5. The “cost” for us is then 3×9 + 5×7 = 27 + 35 = 62. We then have a “budget” of about 153.6 – 62 = 91.6 (in our value‐units) remaining for any further items we might “gift” to Player 2 so that they prefer the deal over their outside option. 

A plausible (and simple) proposal is then to add 2 units of item 2 to Player 2’s allocation. Since item 2 costs us 41 per unit, 2 units cost 82, and the total “cost” becomes 62 + 82 = 144, which is below our 153.6 threshold. 

Under this proposal our counteroffer to Player 2 is:
  x1 = 3, x2 = 2, x3 = 0, x4 = 5, x5 = 0.
Then our own allocation (the complement) is:
  item1: 0, item2: (4–2)=2, item3: 4, item4: (5–5)=0, item5: 6.
Our undiscounted value becomes:
  item2: 2×41 = 82  
  item3: 4×89 = 356  
  item5: 6×66 = 396  
for a total of 82+356+396 = 834.
Discounted at 0.9 this is 0.9×834 = 750.6, which is just above our outside offer of 742.

Meanwhile, Player 2 receives the bundle [3,2,0,5,0]. (Though we do not know their exact private values, giving them all of item 1 and 4 and a couple units of item 2 is likely to be attractive if their outside alternative is uncertain.)

Thus, proposing the division: Player 2 gets [3,2,0,5,0] in round 2 seems a plausible counteroffer that improves our result over accepting the current offer. 

Based on this reasoning, my action is to make the following counteroffer:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [3, 2, 0, 5, 0]}

I then thought about how many items I can “afford” to keep knowing that if I’m too greedy the other side may get too little value compared to what they might get on their own. Although I do not know Player 2’s exact values, we know each player’s value per unit is drawn from Uniform[1,101] (with an average around 51). If we suppose that on average Player 2’s total would be about 26×51 ≈ 1326 and that their outside offer is drawn uniformly up to that total, on average their outside offer would be roughly half that (about 663). In a “fair‐enough” immediate deal the sum of the counts of items given to Player 2 should make their expected value around 663. 

Because there are a total of 26 items across all types, if I “keep” k items then Player 2 would get (26 – k) units. To give them roughly 663 in expected value we want:
  51 × (26 – k) ≈ 663 ⟹ 26 – k ≈ 13 ⟹ k ≈ 13.
That means if I take about 13 units (items) that are most valuable to me I can “afford” to leave the remaining 13 (which on average have a total of about 663 for Player 2) to help induce immediate acceptance.

Looking at my own values, the relative importance is:
 Item 3 (67) > Item 4 (53) > Item 1 (46) > Item 2 (39) > Item 5 (25).
I want to retain as many of my best items as possible while “giving” the opponent the ones I value less. In particular I would like to “sacrifice” items that—although they give a good expected value if they are average—don’t contribute as much to my personal total if I keep them.

A natural idea is then to take:
 • All of item 3 (4 units) and item 4 (5 units) – that gives 9 items.
 • Then take 4 units of item 1 (since it is my third-best) to add up to 13 total units.
That would yield my own payoff as:
 Item 1: 4×46 = 184  
 Item 3: 4×67 = 268  
 Item 4: 5×53 = 265  
Total = 184 + 268 + 265 = 717, which is safely above my outside offer.

The remainder of the items then automatically goes to Player 2:
 • Item 1: remaining 3 of 7  
 • Item 2: all 5 units  
 • Item 3: 0 of 4  
 • Item 4: 0 of 5  
 • Item 5: all 5 units

Thus Player 2’s “offer” is:
 Item 1: 3, Item 2: 5, Item 3: 0, Item 4: 0, Item 5: 5.

Under an average valuation of about 51 per unit for them, the expected value for Player 2 is roughly 13×51 = 663—which is about what they might expect from an outside offer. That should make the offer attractive enough for Player 2 (especially given discounting in later rounds).

Accordingly, I will now propose this initial division.

I will first explain my reasoning.

My total “own‐value” if I got every item is 
  16×4 + 77×1 + 42×1 + 44×4 + 33×6 = 557.
My outside (disagreement) payoff is 515; hence if I “win” the full bundle I gain an extra 42 in my own value. In any deal I must get at least 515 in my own numbers, so the “cost” (in my own value) of any items I concede must not exceed 42.

Because my per‐unit values differ across items, I want to “spend” as little of my surplus (the 42 extra points) as possible while giving the other party items they are likely to prize. In expectation (with their private value drawn uniformly on [1,101]) the other player “values” each unit roughly around 51 on average. Thus, from my perspective the “exchange rate” is best when I give up a unit I value low while potentially handing over something the other player may see as worth about 51. Among my items item 1 is worth only 16 per unit, which is very “cheap” for me (and in expectation the other party may see it as roughly 51 per unit). In contrast, my most‐valued item – item 2 – is too expensive (77) for me to give away.

I must have my final share satisfy:
  557 − [16·(# of item 1 I concede) + 77·(# of item 2) + 42·(# of item 3) + 44·(# of item 4) + 33·(# of item 5)] ≥ 515.
Thus the total “cost” of what I concede must be ≤42. To “spend” as much “bang for my buck” as possible—and since I cannot give fractional items—I see that the best is to give up only item 1’s because 1 unit costs me only 16 while giving the other side (in expectation) around 51 in value. (If I try to concede a unit of any other item I hit a larger “cost” that would drop my own share below 515.) The most I can concede in item 1 is 2 units (since 3 units would cost 48 >42). Giving 2 units of item 1 costs me 2×16 = 32, leaving me with a share valued 557 − 32 = 525—a slight gain (of 10) over my disagreement payoff.

Thus my initial offer is to “give” the other player 2 units of item 1 and keep everything else. (No other item is conceded because any additional concession would reduce my payoff below my outside offer valuation.) 

In the required format my offer is:

I will explain my reasoning.

Step 1. Note our available items and our own private values:
 • Item 1: 5 units, value 49 each (total 245)

 • Item 3: 2 units, value 1 each (total 2)
 • Item 4: 3 units, value 64 each (total 192)
 • Item 5: 6 units, value 54 each (total 324)
So if we got everything our total “pie” is worth 827. We also have an outside option of 406.

Step 2. We know that Player 2’s private per‐unit values are drawn uniformly from 1 to 101. Their expected per–unit value is roughly 51. (Note that while we do not know their exact numbers, we reasonably think that if they got all items their expected total would be about 1020, and their private outside option – drawn uniformly from 1 to 1020 – will average to about 510; however, because discounting is not yet in effect in round 1 but will become an issue in later rounds, Player 2 will end up preferring a “good‐enough” immediate offer as compared to waiting.)

Step 3. As the first mover, we design our offer in such a way that we “give” Player 2 an allocation whose expected value is roughly at or just above what they might be able to get later (discounted by gamma = 0.9) or by their outside option, while keeping for ourselves as many of the items we value highly. Since our values vary by item, we want to “concede” items that are relatively low‐worth for us but that — given the uniform draw — have a higher marginal expected value for Player 2.

Step 4. Look at our items:
 – Item 3 is almost valueless for us (only 1 per unit) but for Player 2 the expected value per unit is about 51. Thus it is very “cheap” for us to give away.
 – Item 2 is also low from our perspective (16 per unit) while giving the opponent around 51 per unit (in expectation).
We can give these away completely.
So we set x₂ = 4 (all units) and x₃ = 2 (all units).

Step 5. With that, Player 2 already gets an expected gain of about
  4×51 + 2×51 = 204 + 102 = 306.
That may not be good enough compared to their likely reservation (~510) but note that if they wait a round the discount (0.9) will bring down their later payoff to around 459 (0.9 × 510). Thus, if we can “top‐up” the offer by roughly 150 extra expected points, they should be inclined to accept now.
The next “cheap” item for us is Item 1: although we value it at 49 per unit, giving one unit means our “loss” is 49 while the opponent gains (in expectation) roughly 51. Three extra units (3×51 ≈ 153) would supply nearly 153 extra expected value.
So by adding x₁ = 3 we can bring the opponent’s expected total value almost to 459 (306 + 3×51 = 306 + 153 = 459), which is roughly equal to what waiting might yield after discounting.

Step 6. We then keep the rest of the items that we value even more (Items 4 and 5) completely.
That means set x₄ = 0 and x₅ = 0.

Step 7. Under this proposed division:
 – The offer to Player 2 is: item 1: 3, item 2: 4, item 3: 2, item 4: 0, item 5: 0.
 – We keep: item 1: (5–3)=2 units, item 2: 0, item 3: 0, item 4: all 3, and item 5: all 6.
Our own total value then comes to:
  2×49 + 3×64 + 6×54 = 98 + 192 + 324 = 614,
which is well above our outside option (406).

This offer is designed to be “just enough” for Player 2 (with an expected value around 459 in today’s terms) while letting us secure a high-value share.

Thus, in round 1 our action is to make the counteroffer with the offer vector [3, 4, 2, 0, 0].

Step 1: We first assess our current “deal‐on the table.” The offer we currently have would give us (as Player 1) a bundle of 4 units of item 1, 0 of item 2, 2 of item 3, 0 of item 4, and 2 of item 5. Using our private per‐unit values (49, 16, 1, 64, 54) the raw score from that bundle is

  4×49 + 0×16 + 2×1 + 0×64 + 2×54 = 196 + 0 + 2 + 0 + 108 = 306. 

Because we are now in round 2 (thus discount factor = 0.9) the present‐value of that outcome is 306×0.9 = 275.4. This is clearly below our private outside offer of 406; so we would not wish to just accept the current offer.

Step 2: We can counteroffer. In constructing a counteroffer we control what we “give to” Player 2; our own bundle is the remainder. Our goal is to secure for ourselves a raw (i.e. undiscounted) value that, when discounted by 0.9, beats our outside option. In other words, if we secure a raw value V then we need 0.9×V ≥ 406, so V must be at least about 451.11. (Since we must use integers and items come in specific quantities, a slightly higher raw score is preferable.)

Step 3: We already know our total possible raw value if we got everything is 827. Thus if we want at least 451 raw for ourselves our “cost” (i.e. the sum of our item‐values that we hand over to Player 2) must be no more than 827 – 451 = 376. In choosing an offer we’d like also to “sweeten” the deal for Player 2 relative to the current state and previous offers so that they are more inclined to accept.

Step 4: One workable counteroffer is the following. In round 1 we offered to give Player 2 the bundle [3, 4, 2, 0, 0] (leaving ourselves 827 – 213 = 614 raw value by our own valuation) but that was rejected. Their proposal (the current offer on the table) would yield us 306 raw. So we consider a compromise move—a counteroffer that gives us a raw value just above the minimum we need while “improving” on what Player 2 would have gotten from our earlier (too generous for us) proposal.

A candidate is to offer Player 2 the bundle [4, 4, 2, 0, 2]. Then our own bundle becomes the complement of totals:
  For item 1: 5 – 4 = 1
  For item 2: 4 – 4 = 0
  For item 3: 2 – 2 = 0
  For item 4: 3 – 0 = 3
  For item 5: 6 – 2 = 4

Step 5: Our raw value for our own bundle is therefore
  1×49 + 0×16 + 0×1 + 3×64 + 4×54 
    = 49 + 0 + 0 + 192 + 216 
    = 457.
When discounted by 0.9 (since this is a round 2 agreement), our present value becomes 457×0.9 = 411.3. This beats our outside offer. At the same time the offer to Player 2 (the bundle [4,4,2,0,2]) is substantially different from the current offer on the table and may be attractive enough for them to accept rather than risk a further round with an even lower discount factor.

Step 6: Given that accepting the current offer nets us a discounted 275.4—which is well below our outside offer—and that this counteroffer secures us over 411 in present‐value terms, our best move is to COUNTEROFFER with the proposed division.

Therefore, my action is:

Step‐by‐step reasoning:
1. Our private values for items are: item 1 = 55, item 2 = 54, item 3 = 22, item 4 = 34, item 5 = 27. Adding our full quantities (5, 5, 5, 3, 4) gives a total “face‐value” of 865.
2. However, any deal reached in round 2 is discounted by a factor of 0.9 (since gamma^(r–1) with r = 2 equals 0.9). Thus, a deal yielding x face‐value is worth 0.9×x to us.
3. Our outside offer (the “walk‐away” value) is 763 – and note that if we walk away, we get that value full (without discounting). Therefore, to prefer any deal over our outside offer we would need 0.9×(our share) ≥ 763, which implies our share (in face‐value terms) must be at least 763/0.9 ≈ 849.
4. The current offer on the table is Player 2 offering us [1, 1, 5, 1, 1]. That allocation gives us a face value of:
  55×1 + 54×1 + 22×5 + 34×1 + 27×1 = 55 + 54 + 110 + 34 + 27 = 280.
 When discounted (0.9×280), its present value is only 252 — far below our 763 reservation.
5. To craft a counteroffer that would get us a face‐value of at least 849 would force us to leave only 865 – 849 = 16 face‐value for Player 2. Given that Player 2’s own outside offer is drawn from his total value (which on expectation is considerably high), a counteroffer skewed so extremely in our favor would be absolutely unacceptable for him.
6. If we delay further or try to propose a counteroffer acceptable to both sides, we cannot meet our reservation value (since discounting makes almost any division unattractive compared to our outside offer) while also offering Player 2 enough to beat his own outside option.
7. Hence, any deal on the table in round 2 is clearly inferior to our outside offer of 763. Rationally, our best move is to WALK away.

{"action": "WALK"}

• On the other hand, Player 2’s value per unit is privately drawn and can be high. Although I cannot be sure what Player 2’s actual value for item 2 is, it is plausible that even 1 unit of item 2 may deliver them a competitive utility compared to their private outside offer (which is drawn from a range up to their overall total).  
• Thus, I choose to make an initial offer in which I give over 1 unit of item 2 (and nothing else) so that I keep nearly all items, ensuring for me at least 608 in value, while hopefully enticing Player 2 to accept if that one unit holds high enough private value for them.

But when discounted in round 2 that becomes 0.9 × 617 = 555.3 which is still less than our outside offer of 600. Moreover, if the negotiations extend to round 3, the discount would be even steeper (0.9^(3–1) = 0.81) further reducing any deal’s value.

Step 5: Conclude the best action. No conceivable allocation available to us in a round‑2 deal could yield a present value exceeding our outside offer of 600. Consequently, no matter what counteroffer we craft, a deal agreed now (or in round 3) would be less valuable than simply taking our outside offer.

I'm thinking along the following lines. We know our total value if we got everything is 398 (5×36 + 5×18 + 57 + 9 + 2×31). Our private outside offer is 100, so any agreement we reach must give us more than 100 (and preferably as high as possible) while still “selling” a deal to Player 2 that is at least as attractive as their own outside offer. We also face discounting (γ = 0.9 for rounds beyond the first); so it is in both parties’ interest to strike an agreement immediately.

Our private values show that for each item type we have a “relative strength” or “relative disadvantage” compared to what Player 2 might expect. (Though we don’t know Player 2’s exact numbers, since they are drawn uniformly from 1 to 101, we can use averages: roughly 51 per unit.) For example:

• Item 2: We value each unit at only 18 (vs. ~51 for Player 2). We definitely want Player 2 to have these.
• Item 3: We value it at 57, which is slightly above an expected 51 for Player 2. We’d like to keep this.
• Item 4: Valued by us at 9 versus ~51 for Player 2. It makes sense for Player 2 to have it.
• Item 5: Valued 31 for us versus ~51 for Player 2. Again, better for them to have these.

In light of this, a promising idea is to “sell” to Player 2 the items that are relatively more valuable for them (by average) while keeping for ourselves the bundle on which we have some comparative advantage. Thus, one natural division is:
 – Give Player 2 every unit of items 2, 4, and 5.
 – Keep for ourselves every unit of items 1 and 3.

Let’s check the numbers:
• Player 1 would get: all 5 units of item 1 and the single unit of item 3. For us this is 5×36 + 57 = 180 + 57 = 237.
• Player 2 would get: all 5 units of item 2, the sole unit of item 4, and both units of item 5. Although we don’t know their exact values, with average estimates that would be roughly: 5×51 + 51 + 2×51 ≈ 255 + 51 + 102 = 408.

Player 2’s expected outside offer is drawn uniformly from 1 to their total possible value, so on average it would be about half of that total (~half of 714 if we assume 14 items at an average of ~51). Even if their outside offer turns out to be a bit high, the fact that this deal is available immediately (with no discount) is an advantage. Meanwhile, our 237 far exceeds our outside offer of 100.

Thus, this seems like a credible first offer that maximizes our share given our relative “strengths” while hoping that the immediate and substantial utility for Player 2 encourages acceptance (at least if their private type isn’t extremely high).

I will try to explain my thinking briefly. (Note that without knowing Player 2’s private values the “right” division is uncertain, so I have to “guess” a division that (a) leaves me well above my outside value (91) and (b) gives Player 2 enough “stuff” so that they might well prefer accepting this deal over waiting—with discounting and the possibility to “counter” later.) 

My total value for all items is 1269, so if I got everything I’d get 1269. A “fair‐looking” (but by no means unique) split from my own perspective might be a roughly 55% versus 45% division of value. (My outside option of 91 is very low compared to 1269 so I have room to “fight” over items—but little is known about Player 2’s fallback; indeed if their private values turn out high they might have a better outside option. In many alternating–offer games the responder’s continuation value is enhanced by discounting, so I would need to “give away” some of the surplus to get agreement immediately.)

A natural idea is to try to “offload” some of the lower–value items for me (items where my per–unit value is low: item 1 is 24 and item 3 is 33) to Player 2, while keeping many of the higher–value items (items 4 and 5, worth 72 and 92, respectively). One rough possibility is to propose that Player 2 get two or three units on each item so that, when the pieces add up, I keep a bundle which by my own numbers is worth roughly 700 and they get a bundle (by my own measure) of a little under 600. (This “unequal” division may be necessary if I suspect that given the game’s structure—discounting plus the possibility that their outside offer may be relatively high—Player 2 will reject a bargain that gives them too little.)

For example, consider the following proposal. (Remember: the offer I submit is the bundle that Player 2 will receive; I get what remains.) Suppose I offer Player 2 the following allocation:
 • Item 1 (5 units total): 2 units to Player 2 (so I get 3)
 • Item 2 (2 units total): 1 unit to Player 2 (I get 1)
 • Item 3 (3 units total): 1 unit to Player 2 (I get 2)
 • Item 4 (5 units total): 2 units to Player 2 (I get 3)
 • Item 5 (6 units total): 3 units to Player 2 (I get 3)

In my own valuation this gives me:
 Item 1: 3 × 24 = 72  
 Item 2: 1 × 69 = 69  
 Item 3: 2 × 33 = 66  
 Item 4: 3 × 72 = 216  
 Item 5: 3 × 92 = 276  
Total = 72 + 69 + 66 + 216 + 276 = 699

And by my own “lens” the offer gives Player 2 (if we roughly assume their per–unit values average about 51) an expected total roughly:
 Item 1: 2 × ~51 = 102  
 Item 2: 1 × ~51 = 51  
 Item 3: 1 × ~51 = 51  
 Item 4: 2 × ~51 = 102  
 Item 5: 3 × ~51 = 153  
Total ≈ 102 + 51 + 51 + 102 + 153 = 459

Given the uncertainty on Player 2’s true private values, this “balanced” offer (giving me about 699 versus about 459 in my scale) is an initial probe. (It is not as favorable for Player 2 as they might want if their outside option is high, but I am the first mover and I can adjust in later rounds.) 

Thus, in round 1 I will offer the bundle in the requested format.

I’ve looked carefully at our current offer. The table currently gives me [1,4,8,0,1] (so I’d get one unit of item 1, four of item 2, eight of item 3, none of item 4, and one of item 5). My own valuations per unit are very skewed: I attach high value to items 1 (83), 4 (83) and item 5 (73) while items 2 (28) and 3 (40) are relatively lower‐value for me. Under the current offer I’d “earn” a gross value of 

  1×83 + 4×28 + 8×40 + 0×83 + 1×73 = 83 + 112 + 320 + 0 + 73 = 588.

Because we’re in round 2 the discount factor 0.9 reduces that “immediate” deal to 588×0.9 = 529.2 in present terms. (Note that if we waited until round 3 any deal would be discounted by 0.9² = 0.81 so even a better gross allocation would be worth less in present‐value terms.) Also, my outside option is only 202.

Looking at my own value structure I’d very much like to have full control over items that I value greatly. For instance, I’d like to secure all of item 1 and the sole unit of item 4. (In the current offer I’d only get 1 of item 1 and none of item 4.) My earlier proposal in round 1 essentially left those “good” items to me (when I offered [0,5,9,0,0]—which would have given me the complement [4,0,0,1,5] worth 4×83 + 1×83 + 5×73 = 780), but Player 2’s counteroffer moved the deal away from that extreme. 

I therefore considered “splitting the difference.” I can propose a new allocation by offering Player 2 a bundle that is a bit closer to what they currently would get (namely, the complement of [1,4,8,0,1] is [3,1,1,1,4]) while still shifting a few high‐value items to me. One option I found is to propose that I give Player 2 the bundle [1,5,8,0,0]. Under that division the totals work out as follows (recall the total quantities available on items 1–5 are [4,5,9,1,5]):

 • I offer Player 2: [1, 5, 8, 0, 0].  
 • Then my own bundle becomes: [4–1, 5–5, 9–8, 1–0, 5–0] = [3, 0, 1, 1, 5].  

My gross value then is:
  3×83 + 0×28 + 1×40 + 1×83 + 5×73  
    = 249 + 0 + 40 + 83 + 365  
    = 737.

Discounted in round 2 this becomes 737×0.9 = 663.3—substantially better than the 529.2 I’d get from accepting the current offer. 

What about Player 2? Under the current proposal they’d have ended up with [3,1,1,1,4], but with my counteroffer they would receive [1,5,8,0,0]. In expectation (given uniformly drawn private values) this shift means they would trade off getting fewer units of item 1 (and not getting item 4) for additional quantity of items 2 and 3. My reasoning is as follows. My total value for all items is 568, and my private “outside offer” guarantees me 472 if I quit negotiations. In any deal I make I must receive an allocation whose items (as valued by my private numbers) total at least 472. That means I can “sacrifice” at most 96 points of value from the full 568. In other words, if I concede items to Player 2, the items I give away can have a total “cost” (using my own per‐unit values) of no more than 96; if I concede more I’d be “worse off” than simply taking my outside offer.

For example, note the following:
 • Item 3 is worth 18 per unit for me but on average is worth roughly 51 per unit to an opponent (since their per–unit value is drawn uniformly between 1 and 101). Thus, if I “give up” one unit of item 3 I lose 18 points but the opponent, if his draw turns out near average, “gains” about 51.
 • Similarly, item 4 is 25 for me and averages 51 for Player 2;
 • In contrast, my high‐value items (item 2 at 100, and even item 5 at 61) are too “expensive” to concede because every unit given to Player 2 would cost me too much relative to the likely gain for him.

Even if I use my “concession budget” as efficiently as possible (by giving away all units of item 3, which cost 18 each) I would be giving away at most 4×18 = 72 points of my own value. That means Player 2 would receive at most 4 units of item 3 and, in expectation (when multiplied by an average of 51 per unit) his “allocated‐value” would be around 204. (I can try combinations with items 3, 4, or even 1, but the arithmetic shows that when keeping my own retained value at or above 472, I cannot “spend” more than 96 of my value—and the most efficient items (item 3 has cost 18 per unit) can at best give up 4 units, totaling an expected gain of about 204 for Player 2.)

Yet on average Player 2’s overall total value of all items (if he got everything) would be about 714 (since for each of the 14 total units the average value is about 51) and his outside offer – drawn uniformly between 1 and his total – would then be around 357 in expectation. In other words, no matter how I “try” to impress him with a concession within the limit that leaves me at least 472 in hand, the maximum expected benefit I can convey is far below his likely reservation value. (Any attempt to give him even more would force me to drop below my safe outside offer.)

Because I cannot “bridge the gap” to provide Player 2 with an allocation that likely exceeds his own outside option without reducing my own allocation below 472 (and thus worse than simply accepting my outside offer), a rational, risk‐averse strategy is not to negotiate now. In other words, by “walking away” from negotiations I guarantee myself my outside offer of 472 rather than risk a deal that in almost every situation would be rejected or, if later accepted, come in at an even lower (discounted) value.

My private outside offer is 225, which I’d receive if I “WALK” away. In round 2 a deal would have its value discounted by γ = 0.9 (since discounting is applied as γ^(round–1) so round 2 gives a multiplier of 0.9).

For example, if I were to concede 2 units of item 3 (a cost of 2×9 = 18) then my share would be 271 – 18 = 253 (discounted to 227.7). Compared with their own previous offer (which would let them have more of item 3, plus additional items from the leftovers), such a counteroffer is very unattractive to them. (I have no way of knowing their actual private values, but the outside offer mechanism means they too have a fallback and their expected “outside” value is likely much higher than what a token [0, 0, 2, 0, 0] would give.)

Thus, any counteroffer I attempt that “beats” my own outside offer would have to sacrifice so little (only 21 value units out of 271) that it leaves Player 2 with only a marginal allocation. In the current situation Player 2’s previous offer (giving me [2,1,2,0,0] and keeping almost everything else) is far less attractive for me, but it almost certainly is much better for them than almost any counteroffer I could craft without endangering my own discounted value (which must be at least 225).

Because:
 – Accepting the current offer would yield me only about 107 in present‐value.
 – Making a counteroffer within my “safety margin” leads to a proposal that is almost surely unacceptable to Player 2 (given their likely outside offer, and the fact they fetched a far “generous” allocation for themselves in round 1).
 – And if we fail to reach an agreement in round 2 then we run into round 3 where the discount is even steeper (0.9² = 0.81) and, in addition, if Player 2 counteroffers then it counts as a WALK on their side.

In short, if I try to negotiate a deal in round 2 I can only hope for an outcome that gives me less than my safe outside offer of 225. Thus, the best action available is to WALK away and take my outside offer.

{"action": "WALK"}

Step 1: My “pie” (i.e. the total value of all items to me) is 612, with my private values:
 • Item 1: 1×74 = 74  
 • Item 2: 2×10 = 20  
 • Item 3: 6×60 = 360  
 • Item 4: 3×30 = 90  
 • Item 5: 4×17 = 68  
Thus, my total = 612, and my outside offer is 400. This means any deal I accept must yield me at least 400 points (undiscounted in round 1).

Step 2: Although I do not know Player 2’s true per‐unit values, we know each of their values is drawn uniformly from 1 to 101 so that the expected per‐unit value is about 51. (For example, the expected full value if they got every unit would be roughly 16×51 = 816; indeed, their outside offer is drawn between 1 and that total.)

Step 3: As the offer-maker, I can “design” the division. I want to keep those items that are highly valuable to me and offer Player 2 items that I value less but that—on average—should be reasonably attractive to them. My personal ranking is:
 – Item 1: 74 per unit (very high)
 – Item 3: 60 per unit (high)
 – Item 4: 30 per unit (moderate)
 – Item 5: 17 per unit (low)
 – Item 2: 10 per unit (lowest)

Step 4: In light of my fallback of 400 versus a full pie of 612, I must secure at least 400 for myself. At the same time I want Player 2 to receive roughly an “acceptable” share relative to what they might get if they walked away (their outside offer is drawn from [1, Total] and its expected value is near 408). A strategy is to let Player 2 have items I value little but which—given their likely average per‐unit value of 51—deliver them expected value near or above 408.

Step 5: Notice that item 2 (2 units), item 5 (4 units) are the least important for me. In expected terms, if I give Player 2 these:
 – Item 2: 2×51 ≈ 102  
 – Item 5: 4×51 ≈ 204  
Total ≈ 306. This is a bit short of what we think Player 2 might need for acceptance. Adding all of item 4 (3 units) adds roughly 3×51 ≈ 153; making the total about 459 (306+153), which is comfortably above an expected fallback.

Step 6: Under this proposal, Player 2 would receive:
 • Item 1: 0 (I keep the 1 unit worth 74 to me)  
 • Item 2: all 2 units (worth 10 each to me, total 20)  
 • Item 3: 0 (I want all 6 because they yield 360 to me)  
 • Item 4: all 3 units (worth 30 each to me, total 90)  
 • Item 5: all 4 units (worth 17 each to me, total 68)
This yields for me: keeping items 1 and 3 gives 74 + 360 = 434, higher than my fallback 400.
Player 2, by the “average value” expectation, gets roughly (2+3+4)×51 = 9×51 = 459, which seems acceptable.

Step 7: Since this offer is a valid division of the items (it does not exceed available units for any item) and meets both our reservation concerns (I get 434, above my fallback; Player 2 gets an offer with expected value around 459), I will propose it as my initial offer.

Thus, my action in round 1 is to make a counteroffer giving Player 2: [0, 2, 0, 3, 4].

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [0, 2, 0, 3, 4]}

round_data.response:
I’ll explain my reasoning first.

Step 1. Value of the current offer:
• The current offer on the table is [1, 2, 1, 1, 2] (which means you would receive, for each item type, 1 unit of item 1, 2 of item 2, etc.).
• My private per‐unit values are: item 1 = 74, item 2 = 10, item 3 = 60, item 4 = 30, and item 5 = 17.
• Thus, if I accept the current offer I’d get:
  item 1: 1×74 = 74  
  item 2: 2×10 = 20  
  item 3: 1×60 = 60  
  item 4: 1×30 = 30  
  item 5: 2×17 = 34  
  Total = 74 + 20 + 60 + 30 + 34 = 218.
• Because we are in round 2 and outcomes are discounted by gamma^(r–1) with gamma = 0.9 (so a 0.9 multiplier now), the present value is 218×0.9 = 196.2.
• My current outside offer is 400, so this is far less favorable.

Step 2. Designing a counteroffer:
• I know that if I reject this offer and walk away I would get 400 (undiscounted). In order for a deal reached in round 2 to beat my outside option I need my “undiscounted” deal value to be high enough so that 0.9×(my deal value) is at least 400. That is, my deal value must be at least 400/0.9 ≈ 444.44.
• Since the total maximum value (if I got everything) is 612, the maximum “concession” I can make (i.e. the amount of my value I am willing to give up) is 612 – 444.44 ≈ 167.56. (I must keep at least 444.44 in undiscounted value to beat my outside option after discounting.)
• Now I choose which items I’m more willing to concede. I value item 1 very highly (74 per unit) and item 3 almost as much (60 per unit), so I want to keep all of those. The lower‐value items for me are item 2 (10 per unit), item 4 (30 per unit), and item 5 (17 per unit). It thus makes sense to “give” these to Player 2 in my counteroffer.
• A natural, “clean” proposal is to offer all of item 2 (2 units) and all of item 5 (4 units) and a partial amount of item 4 so that I don’t concede too much. Conceding all of item 2 and 5 gives me a “loss” of:  
  2×10 (item 2) + 4×17 (item 5) = 20 + 68 = 88.  
• I can then consider conceding some of item 4. If I concede 2 out of 3 units (i.e. offer 2 units of item 4 to Player 2), that is an additional concession of 2×30 = 60.
• Total concession (loss on my side) = 88 + 60 = 148.
• Then my retained items would be:
  item 1: keep all 1 unit  
  item 2: keep 0 (since 2 offered)  
  item 3: keep all 6 units  
  item 4: keep the remaining 1 out of 3  
  item 5: keep 0 (since 4 offered)  
  So my total value becomes:  
  1×74 + 6×60 + 1×30 = 74 + 360 + 30 = 464.
• After discounting in round 2, my present value is 464×0.9 = 417.6, which is above my outside offer of 400.
• The counteroffer (“offer” means what I am giving to Player 2) in this proposal is then: [0, 2, 0, 2, 4]. (It complies with the available units on each type.)

Step 3. Decision:
• Accepting the current offer would give me only about 196.2 in present-value terms.
• Walking away gives me 400.
• By making this counteroffer I aim for a deal that would yield me 464 (undiscounted) and 417.6 (discounted) – which is an improvement over my outside offer. (Of course, I do not know Player 2’s exact values, but this seems to be a rational improvement.)
• So I will make a counteroffer.

Thus, my action is to send the following counteroffer:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [0, 2, 0, 2, 4]}
